Dear Sheffield City Council,
Could you please provide the following recorded information in relation to the John Lewis building.
Records that were created or touched upon the councils purchase of the building. The deal was complete in Aug 2020, the council will be privy to when they considered buying the premises.
1. Any report, assessment memo, surveys, communication in relation to structural and or asbestos problems.
Where any email communication is found, please provide as much as the email chain as possible.
2. Any report, assessment memo, surveys, record, communication in relation to mainitence of air conditioning, lifts and escalators.
3. Any report, assessment memo, surveys, record, communication in relation to Revamping, refurbishing or rebuilding the site.
Vast public interest in how taxpayers money was spent. The council gave a press release stating it was a 20 year lease signed, only for less than a year later be left with an empty building.
https://www.thestar.co.uk/business/sheff...
https://www.thestar.co.uk/business/sheff...
Yours faithfully,
Marcus

Dear Marcus Combie,
Thank you for your request for information relating to John Lewis building
and structural or asbestos problems which we received on 05/11/2021.
Please find Sheffield City Council’s response to your request set out
below:
The information you have requested is exempt from disclosure under section
12 of the Freedom of Information Act 2000. Sheffield City Council does
hold the information you have requested. However, we do not record the
information in a format that allows us to produce an electronic report of
this. Therefore, we would have to carry out a manual search of our
records. We estimate that we would need to search a year’s worth of
records from a multitude of sources. Therefore, it is estimated it would
take us 111 hours (around 3 weeks) to collate the information, which is
more than the cost limit of 18 hours or £450 specified in the [1]Freedom
of Information and Data Protection (Appropriate Limit and Fees)
Regulations 2004 (SI 2004 No. 3244).
Under section 16 of the Freedom of Information Act 2000, we have a duty to
provide advice and assistance to requesters.
Officers are presenting summary condition reports (structure, plant and
equipment as per the information sought) including information on asbestos
as background papers to the report. Those papers will be made public on
the 8^th of December ahead of the Co-operative Executive meeting on the
15^th of December 2021 via the following link: [2]Sheffield City Council -
Browse meetings - Co-operative Executive. This might assist you re-focus
your request within the “appropriate limit”.
If you would like to narrow down the focus of your request, we would be
happy to process your revised request as a new request for information
under the Freedom of Information Act 2000.
If you have any queries about this response, please do not hesitate to
contact us.
The information provided in this response is available for re-use under
the terms of the Open Government Licence v3.0. The terms of the OGL can be
found [3]here. When re-using the information, Sheffield City Council
requires you to include the following attribution statement: “Contains
public sector information obtained from Sheffield City Council and
licensed under the Open Government Licence v3.0.”
If you are unhappy with the response you have received in relation to your
request, you are entitled to have this reviewed. You can ask for an
internal review by replying to this email. Internal review requests should
be submitted within 40 working days from the date of this response.
If you remain dissatisfied with the outcome of your internal review, you
can contact the Information Commissioner’s Office. Please see
[4]
https://ico.org.uk/make-a-complaint/offi...
for further details.
Kind Regards,
Sheffield City Council
PO Box 1283
Sheffield, S1 1UJ
Email: [5][Sheffield City Council request email]

Dear Sheffield City Council,
Please pass this on to the person who conducts Freedom of Information reviews.
I am writing to request an internal review of Sheffield City Council's handling of my FOI request 'John Lewis building, Bakers Pool'.
You have calculated that gathering this information will exceed the cost limit, but I believe that this is an overestimation of the resource required.
For example the council states:
“ However, we do not record the information in a format that allows us to produce an electronic report of this. Therefore, we would have to carry out a manual search of our records. ”
The time the building was purchased was during Covid, and alot of the SCC staff were working remote.
The request finds it highly improbable that the council has no method to search for the records other than a manual search/review. A feasible solution would be reach out to the  team that handled the purchase, and ask them to search their emails during the relevant time spans for the relevant keywords, the same would go for the sharepoint folder, or whatever content manager the council uses for such projects.
Regarding the councils section 16 Application:
“ Officers are presenting summary condition reports (structure, plant and
equipment as per the information sought) including information on asbestos
as background papers to the report. Those papers will be made public on
the 8^th of December ahead of the Co-operative Executive meeting on the
15^th of December 2021 via the following link: [2]Sheffield City Council - “
Officers are presenting summary condition reports (structure, plant and equipment as per the information sought) - but its not the information the requeator is requesting. It fails on a couple of issues.
1. The requestor is seeking the information the council touched upon or created during the purchase of the building, as specfifed in the request. Not summary reports after the fact. The requestor is seeking to know (or didnt) and what the council was in possesion of and relied upon while making the purchase.
2.  It will also not address this request for information:
“ Any report, assessment memo, surveys, record, communication in relation  to Revamping, refurbishing or rebuilding the site. “ Which the council made multiple statements to the press about…
“ If you would like to narrow down the focus of your request, we would be happy to process your revised request as a new request for information “
The requestor does not believe this is necessary, the requestor believes the scope is sufficently narrow, with a limited timespan the council shoule be aware of. The requestor has made suggestions as to how the council couls proceed with the search for recorded information. Which seems reasonable.
A full history of my FOI request and all correspondence is available on the Internet at this address:
http://www.whatdotheyknow.com/request/jo...
Yours faithfully,
Marcus Combie

Dear Marcus Combie,

Lewis building and structural or asbestos problems which we received on

response.
This has now been logged and will be carried out by a member of the team.
Please be aware that Sheffield City Council’s response to the global
COVID-19 pandemic has led to a reduction in resources across the Council,
meaning that we are currently dealing with a backlog of requests.
The Freedom of Information Code of Practice states that we should aim to
your request for internal review within 20 working days, by 06/01/2022,
but we kindly ask for your patience as we anticipate that there may be a
delay in some cases. Please do not hesitate to contact us at the email
address below if you have any queries.
Please note that the Code of Practice does allow us to extend this
deadline by an additional 20 days in some situations. If we need more time
to complete the internal review, we will contact you to inform you of
this.
If you have any queries in the meantime, please contact us at the email
address below.
Yours sincerely,
Sheffield City Council

Sheffield, S1 1UJ
